article_text:
Old-Fashioned Corn Roast Festival set Friday-Saturday in downtown Loveland

Corn-eating contest participants, from left, Isaac Jujan, 13, Maddi Rozeski, 13, and James Andreski, 12, munch on ears of corn last year during the Old Fashion Corn Roast Festival in downtown Loveland. ( Steve Stoner / Loveland Reporter-Herald )

Corn Roast Schedule 8 a.m.-7 p.m. Old-Fashioned Corn Roast Festival on Fourth Street with vendors, food, music and amusements for all ages. 8:30 a.m. Old-Fashioned Corn Roast Parade (an hour earlier than last year). 11:30 a.m. The Women's USA Pro Challenge (stage 2) leaves from The Ranch, 5280 Arena Circle and rides through downtown Loveland on its route. 11:45 a.m. The Men's USA Pro Challenge (stage 6) leaves from The Ranch and rides through downtown Loveland on its route. 11 a.m.-1:30 p.m. Live music begins on Fourth Street in Loveland at the Corn Roast by Soul School. 1:45 p.m. Corn Roast Parade winners announced. 2:30 p.m. Corn-eating contest. 4 p.m. Loveland Rotary Duck Race. 4:30-6:30 p.m. Live music by Cable Ten. For details about the festival, visit www.loveland.org/CornRoastEntertainment/index.php

Officials with the Old-Fashioned Corn Roast Festival are again pleased the event will coincide with the USA Pro Challenge.

While visitors are in town to watch the race sweep down First Street and Fifth Street through the heart of Loveland, they can stop at the festival on Fourth Street for all the corn, music and artisan wares they could desire.

Advertisement

Mindy McCloughan, president and CEO of the Loveland Chamber of Commerce, and Cindy Mackin with the city of Loveland, have worked closely to make the event happen in conjunction with the race.

"This mirrors what we did two years ago," McCloughan said on Thursday. "Because so much work was put into it the first year, it's like a well-oiled machine this year."

Everything will take place on Fourth Street as it has for the last two years.

Events for the Corn Roast will kick off Friday with an introduction of the parade marshals Phil and Janice Farley at 5 p.m. The corn-shucking contest will follow at 5:30 p.m. with over 35 teams ready to shuck corn as fast as they can for the win. All that corn will be boiled and roasted for public consumption and sold that day and all the next day. The Retro Eighties Tribute Band will perform at 8-10 p.m. that night.

The parade will start at 8:30 a.m. Saturday, an hour earlier than it did last year, to account for the racers coming through Loveland at around noon.

McCloughan said that 100 floats are registered for the parade, and they had to turn teams away for both the corn-shucking contest and parade because there was so much interest. The parade theme will again be Tour de Corn, as it was two years ago when the USA Pro Challenge first came through.

"Early on we made sure to engage with Mindy and her planning to make sure we had programming downtown with one thing after another," said Cindy Mackin with Visit Loveland, a tourism branch of the city of Loveland.

Mackin said the city hired a band, Soul School, to start performing right after the parade finished, around 10:30 a.m. so that something festive was going on even before the USA Pro Challenge men's and women's cyclists come through.

The cyclists are scheduled to leave The Ranch at 11:30-11:45 a.m. and will be downtown around noon and a little after.

Soul School will break as the cyclists come through and will pick up again after until around 1:30 p.m.

"So people can come spend the whole day with the entertainment and the Corn Roast events and the local stores," Mackin said. "I want people to come and stay and visit Loveland; shop, eat and play."

She said the city is excited to work with Mindy because the events compliment each other well.

"Hopefully those that stay downtown will be eating in restaurants, shopping, enjoying the nightlife," McCloughan added.

Saturday's events will include visits from the Corn Roast mascot, Sweetie, as well as a kids' zone, beer garden and food.

Children's activities will include bounce houses, water balls, high ropes course, pony rides and petting zoo.

Food vendors will be stationed by the parking lot across from Aims Community College at Fourth Street and Railroad Avenue. The corn cooker and selling area will be by the Sports Station.

Payments will be on a token system, which can be purchased at three token booths. Participating restaurants will even allow tokens to be used in their businesses for several days after the festival.

McCloughan said they estimate 15,000 to 20,000 people visited the Corn Roast in 2014 and 30,000 were there the year before. They ordered 20,000 ears of corn this year instead of the 15,000 ears of last year.

Around 200 volunteers will be on hand to assist throughout the weekend.

"This year and last year we asked our valentines stamping volunteers to help us bag tokens," McCloughan said. "It takes so many booths on the ground to pull off an event of this magnitude. Come bring your whole family and be prepared to enjoy a great weekend."

Shuttle Stop Locations

Two shuttle buses will run every hour from 5 to 9:55 p.m. Friday and 7:30 a.m. to 7:25 p.m. Saturday.

Shuttles will stop at:

• Corn Roast Festival, Fifth Street and Cleveland Avenue at 10 minutes after the hour.

• Rocky Mountain Center for Innovation and Technology, 815 14th St. SW at 20 minutes after the hour.

• Orchard's Shopping Center, 261 E. 29th St. on the hour.

Drop off at:

• Corn Roast Festival, Fifth Street and Cleveland Avenue at 35 minutes after the hour. From 8 a.m. to noon on Saturday, the dropoff will be at Eighth and Cleveland and between noon and 1 p.m., there will not be shuttle service.

Jessica Benes: 970-669-5050 ext. 530, jbenes@reporter-herald.com, Twitter.com/jessicabenes.
